support_summary: The ribosomal protein RACK1 acts as a scaffold to recruit TDP-43 to polyribosomes. This interaction can lead to the repression of global protein synthesis when TDP-43 levels are elevated in the cytoplasm.

functions.cellular_process: TDP-43 interacts with the ribosomal protein RACK1, a scaffold on the 40S ribosomal subunit. This interaction allows TDP-43 to associate with polyribosomes.
functions.effect_description: When TDP-43 levels increase in the cytoplasm, its association with RACK1 on ribosomes leads to the repression of global protein synthesis. This suggests that cytoplasmic TDP-43 gains a toxic function as a general translational repressor.
biological_consequence: Increased cytoplasmic TDP-43 → Binding to RACK1 on ribosomes → Repression of global translation → Impaired cellular homeostasis → Promotion of cytoplasmic inclusion formation
specific_effects: The interaction between TDP-43 and RACK1 mediates the binding of TDP-43 to the translational machinery.
Increased cytoplasmic TDP-43 represses global protein synthesis, an effect that can be rescued by RACK1 overexpression.
RACK1 co-localizes with TDP-43 in pathological inclusions in motor neurons of ALS patients.
Loss of ribosomal RACK1 reduces the formation of TDP-43 cytoplasmic inclusions.

evidence.paper_title: Increased cytoplasmic TDP-43 reduces global protein synthesis by interacting with RACK1 on polyribosomes

mechanism: TDP-43 interacts with the ribosomal protein RACK1, a scaffold on the 40S ribosomal subunit. This interaction allows TDP-43 to associate with polyribosomes.
effect: When TDP-43 levels increase in the cytoplasm, its association with RACK1 on ribosomes leads to the repression of global protein synthesis. This suggests that cytoplasmic TDP-43 gains a toxic function as a general translational repressor.
summary: TDP43 inhibits RACK1 to modulate global protein synthesis, ultimately affecting promotion of cytoplasmic inclusion formation.
